timeline.bodyText:
Maybe I am confused, but this is changing from number of children to number of siblings?
ast.getParent().getNumberOfChildren() != 1
to
ast.hasNextSibling() || ast.getParent().getFirstChild() != ast
I am not grasping the equality of this.
timeline.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText:
The ast parent can't have zero children, as it already have one child: the ast itself.
This expression should be ast.getParent().getNumberOfChildren()  > 1.
The first version of this method was named isLonelyChild(ast), but was inverted later to avoid negation in (!allowInSwitchCase || !isLonelyChild(ast)).
replies.author: pbludov

replies.bodyText:
Thanks, it is clearer to me now.

ast.getParent().getFirstChild() != ast

Since we are looking for a lonely child, would it be better to swap the above with ast.getPreviousSibling() != null? Then we are only looking at the next/previous sibling and not involving the parent.
replies.author: rnveach

replies.bodyText:

That makes sense. The method is rewritten.
